DLV
Class Predicate

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--DLV.Predicate
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.lang.Cloneable
public class Predicate
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Cloneable

This class allows to handle predicates (which corresponds to tables in a relational database).
A Predicate object may be part of a Model or it can be created to handle the input of DLV in a object oriented modality. You may use a predicate object which is part of a model as input for a new DLV invocation but if you would modify it without modifying the model you must clone it before using clone().


Two interfaces are provided. The first is java.util.Enumeration like the latter is java.sql.ResultSet like.

            Ex. 1.1 - How to work with predicates (Enumeration like)

        ...
        Model m=... // given a Model object m
        ...

        while (m.hasMorePredicates())
        {
         Predicate pred=m.nextPredicate();     // gets a predicate from m
         while(pred.hasMoreFacts())            // iterate Facts contained in pred
         {
          Fact f=pred.nextFact();           // gets a Fact
          f.invert();                       // inverts fact
          .. // do something else with f
         }
        }
        
            Ex. 1.2 - How to work with predicates (ResultSet like)

        ...
        Model m=... // given a Model object m
        ...

        while (m.next())
        {
         Predicate pred=m.getPredicate();     // gets a predicate from m
         while(pred.next())            // iterate Facts contained in pred
         {
          Fact f=pred.getFact();           // gets a Fact
          f.invert();                       // inverts fact
          .. // do something else with f
         }
        }
        
            Ex. 2.1 - How to build a predicate (built in method)

        // we want build a predicate like that user("John","Red"). user("James","Bond").

        Predicate pred=new Predicate("user",2);     // builds a Predicate object ( a table )

        String[2] terms={"John","Red"};               // adds facts
        pred.addFact(pred.new Fact(terms));
        terms={"James","Bond"}
        pred.addFact(pred.new Fact(terms));

        
            Ex. 2.2 - How to build a predicate (ResultSet like method)

        // we want build a predicate like that user("John","Red"). user("James","Bond").

        Predicate pred=new Predicate("user",2);     // builds a Predicate object ( a table )

        pred.moveToInsertRow();               // add facts
        pred.updateString(1,"John");
        pred.updateString(2,"Red");
        pred.insertRow();
        pred.moveToInsertRow();
        pred.updateString(1,"James");
        pred.updateString(2,"Bond");
        pred.insertRow();

Version:
2.0
Author:
Francesco Ricca
See Also:
Dlv, Model, java.sql.ResultSet

updateFact

public void updateFact(Predicate.Fact fact)
This method updates (replace) the fact currently pointed by the cursor if it exists, otherwise NoSuchFactException is thrown.

Parameters:
fact - the new version of the fact.
Throws:
NoSuchFactException - if you try to update a fact which doesn't exist.
BadArityException - if term length is less than the arity of the Predicate.

                       Predicate.Fact fact)

Parameters:

Throws:
NoSuchFactException - if you try to update a fact which doesn't exist.
BadArityException - if term length is less than the arity of the Predicate.
java.lang.NullPointerException - if fact is null.

removeFact

public void removeFact()
This method removes the current fact if it exists, otherwise no operation is performed.

removeFact

public void removeFact(int i)
This method removes the i-th fact if it exists, otherwise no operation is performed.

Parameters:
i - the position of the fact that you would remove from this Predicate.

addFact

public void addFact(Predicate.Fact fact)
This method append a new Fact to this Predicate. If "fact" belongs to another Predicate object, a new Fact object, which belongs to this Predicate object, is created and added to this. The new Fact has the same terms of "fact".

Parameters:
fact - The Fact object you would add.
Throws:
java.lang.NullPointerException - if "fact" is null
BadArityException - if "fact" arity differs from the arity of this Predicate.

hasMoreFacts

public boolean hasMoreFacts()
This method returns true if there are more facts. This method is useful to iterate inside a Predicate object.

Returns:
true if there are more facts, false otherwise.

nextFact

public Predicate.Fact nextFact()
This method returns the next fact. It moves the cursor a position down and then returns the fact pointed by it. This method is useful to iterate inside a Predicate object.

Returns:
The next fact.
Throws:
NoSuchFactException - if you try to get a fact which doesn't exist.

previousFact

public Predicate.Fact previousFact()
This method returns the previous fact. It moves the cursor a position up and then returns the fact pointed by it. This method is useful to iterate inside a Predicate object.

Returns:
The previous fact.
Throws:
NoSuchFactException - if you try to get a fact which doesn't exist.

firstFact

public Predicate.Fact firstFact()
This method returns the first fact and sets the cursor at the first position of this Predicate. This method is useful to iterate inside a Predicate object.

Returns:
The first fact of this Predicate.
Throws:
NoSuchFactException - if you try to get a fact which doesn't exist.

lastFact

public Predicate.Fact lastFact()
This method returns the last fact and set the cursor at the last position of this Predicate. (After calling this method you can call nextFact() an other time without throwing a NoSuchFactException) This method is useful to iterate inside a Predicate object.

Returns:
The last fact of this Predicate.
Throws:
NoSuchFactException - if you try to get a fact which doesn't exist.

getCursor

public int getCursor()
This method returns the position of current fact. If it returns -1 the cursor is before the first fact. The call of getCursor() is the same as getRow()-1.

Returns:
The position of the current fact.

first

public boolean first()
This method moves the cursor to the first Fact in this Predicate object.

Returns:
true if the cursor is on a valid Fact; false if there are no Facts in the Predicate

last

public boolean last()
This method moves the cursor to the last Fact in this Predicate object.

Returns:
true if the cursor is on a valid Fact; false if there are no Facts in the Predicate

beforeFirst

public void beforeFirst()
Moves the cursor to the front of this Predicate object, just before the first Fact. This method has no effect if the Predicate contains no Facts.

afterLast

public void afterLast()
Moves the cursor to the end of this Predicate object, just after the last Fact. This method has no effect if the Predicate contains no Facts.

isFirst

public boolean isFirst()
Indicates whether the cursor is on the first Fact of this Predicate object.

Returns:
true if the cursor is on the first Fact; false otherwise

isLast

public boolean isLast()
Indicates whether the cursor is on the last Fact of this Predicate object.

Returns:
true if the cursor is on the last Fact; false otherwise

relative

public boolean relative(int i)
Moves the cursor a relative number of positions, either positive or negative. Attempting to move beyond the first/last Fact in the Predicate positions the cursor before/after the the first/last Fact. Calling relative(0) is valid, but does not change the cursor position. Note: Calling the method relative(1) is different from calling the method next() because is makes sense to call next() when there is no current Fact, for example, when the cursor is positioned before the first Fact or after the last Fact of the Predicate.

Returns:
true if the cursor is on a Fact; false otherwise

previous

public boolean previous()
Moves the cursor to the previous Fact in this Predicate object.

Returns:
true if the cursor is on a valid position; false if it is off the Predicate

next

public boolean next()
Moves the cursor down one position from its current. A Predicate cursor is initially positioned before the first Fact; the first call to the method next makes the first Fact the current Fact; the second call makes the second Fact the current Fact, and so on.

Returns:
true if the new current position is valid; false if there are no more Facts.

getRow

public int getRow()
Retrieves the current row number. The first row is number 1, the second number 2, and so on.

Returns:
the current row number; 0 if there is no current row

absolute

public boolean absolute(int row)
Moves the cursor to the given "row number" (in a relational view) in this Predicate object. If the row number is positive, the cursor moves to the given row number with respect to the beginning of the result set. The first row is row 1, the second is row 2, and so on.

If the given row number is negative, the cursor moves to an absolute row position with respect to the end of the result set. For example, calling absolute(-1) positions the cursor on the last row (the cursor points the last Fact); calling absolute(-2) moves the cursor to the next-to-last row (the cursor points the next-to-last Fact), and so on.

An attempt to position the cursor beyond the first/last row in the Predicate leaves the cursor before the first Fact or after the last Fact.

Note: Calling absolute(1) is the same as calling first(). Calling absolute(-1) is the same as calling last().

Parameters:
row - the number of the row which the cursor should move to. A positive number indicates the row number counting from the beginning of the Predicate; a negative number indicates the row number counting from the end of the Predicate
Returns:
true if the cursor is on the Predicate; false otherwise

saveTo

public void saveTo(java.lang.String file)
            throws java.io.IOException
This method allows to save this Predicate in the file "file". The file "file" is overwritten by this method if it already exists, otherwise a new file is created. The file created by this method can be reused as input of DLV.

Throws:
java.io.IOException - if an error occurs during file creation.

appendTo

public void appendTo(java.io.PrintWriter out)
              throws java.io.IOException
This method allows to save this Predicate in the file handled by "out". This Predicate is appended if "out" already exists. Be sure that "out" is open before call this method. This method doesn't close "out". The file modified by this method could be reused as input of DLV.

Throws:
java.io.IOException - if an error occurs processing "out".

getFacts

public java.util.Enumeration getFacts()
This method returns an Enumeration of the Facts of this Predicate.

toString

public java.lang.String toString()
Overrides:
toString in class java.lang.Object

clone

public java.lang.Object clone()
Returns a clone of this Predicate. If this predicate is part of a model the cloned predicate won't be part of it.

Overrides:
clone in class java.lang.Object

updateBoolean

public void updateBoolean(int columnIndex,
                          boolean x)
Updates the designated column with a boolean value. The updateXXX methods are used to update column values in the current row or within the the insert row. The updateXXX methods do not update the underlying Predicate; instead the updateRow or insertRow methods are called to update the Predicate.

Parameters:
columnIndex - The first column is 1, the second is 2, ...
x - The new column value.

getString

public java.lang.String getString(int columnIndex)
Gets the value of the designated column in the current row of this Predicate object as a String object in the Java programming language. In DLV syntax strings are quoted. This method removes quotes from the string if ConversionType.QUOTED_STRING is the type specified for this column in meta data informations.

Returns:
the column value; if the value is SQL NULL, the value returned is null.

getTime

public java.sql.Time getTime(int columnIndex)
Gets the value of the designated column in the current row of this Predicate object as a java.sql.Time object in the Java programming language. In DLV syntax strings are quoted. This method removes quotes from the string.

Returns:
the column value; if the value is SQL NULL, the value returned is null.

moveToInsertRow

public void moveToInsertRow()

moveToCurrentRow

public void moveToCurrentRow()
Moves the cursor to the remembered cursor position, usually the current row. This method has no effect if the cursor is not on the insert row

insertRow

public void insertRow()
Inserts the contents of the insert row into this Predicate objaect and into the database. The cursor must be on the insert row when this method is called.

updateRow

public void updateRow()
Updates the underlying Predicate object with the new contents of the current row. This method cannot be called when the cursor is on the insert row.
